channel.title: Need help with simple general programming if possible!
channel.description: i need to code this can anyone help me or teach me if possible? please reply with any way i can contact you , thanks. Write a Java Class called FindPrimes that computes and find the number of Prime numbers between 2 and an upper bound limit set by the user. The Class should comprise the following: 1. An instance variable, limit, of type static and int to represent the upper bound limit. 2. A non-parameterized constructor that sets limit to zero. 3. A parameterized constructor that takes one integer parameter and sets limit to the value of the parameter. Before doing that it checks whether or not the value of the parameter is negative. If it is, the constructor ends the program. 4. One mutator and one accessor method to set and get the value of the instance variable. 5. A main() method where a Scanner object and a FindPrimes object are created. Then, the program finds the prime numbers between 2 and the value of the instance variable limit. To do this main() uses a method IsPrime() that checks whether or not a number is prime. 6. The method IsPrime() takes an int argument (the number to be checked) and returns true if the number is prime and false if not. 7. A prime number is a number that divides by 1 and by itself only. (Hint: for a given number r, divide r by 2, then by 3, ..., until square root of r (inclusive), and check the remainder. if the remainder is zero 0 for any number between 2 and square root of r, then r is NOT prime). 8. After computing the number of primes between 2 and limit, main() will display a ratio of the number of primes by the total of the number between 1 and limit. Example: between 1 and 30 the program should find 10 primes. The ratio of primes is (100) * 10/30 which 33.33 %

item.title: Need help with simple general programming if possible!
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

object:

Ashi: Your first example won’t even compile. You cannot assign instance variables in a static context. The “this.upperBound = upperBound;” part. Instead, write the name of the class rather than “this”. Anyway, I expect that you already know this. If you do, let this be a hint to leoshiro, for how he or she should fix it.

My mistake. I don’t usually make static setters often so it’s a little habit using this.

Read full topic
item.source: Need help with simple general programming if possible!

item.title: Need help with simple general programming if possible!
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“object, post:15, topic:550519”][quote]

  1. An instance variable, limit, of type static and int to represent the upper bound limit.
    [/quote]

They want us to create an instance variable, named “limit”. But they want this instance variable to be “static”. Then it’s not an instance variable anymore.[/quote]His code wouldn’t know any different lul

item.title: Need help with simple general programming if possible!
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

1. An instance variable, limit, of type static and int to represent the upper bound limit.

They want us to create an instance variable, named “limit”. But they want this instance variable to be “static”. Then it’s not an instance variable anymore.

item.title: Need help with simple general programming if possible!
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

You wouldn’t make a instance of a class which doesn’t have any variables/constants of it’s own (The class only have static variables.). Therefore it was implied that you were talking about static methods since those are the only methods you can call without creating an instance.

Point 4 sounds like it want him to return a single instance of the class and have it work as a singleton, but then again the static variable doesn’t make sense. But what can we expect, it seems like the instructor or whoever gave him this assignment is trolling him. And next class they are told why this way of doing this is utterly shit and that they should never do it again.

Read full topic
item.source: Need help with simple general programming if possible!

item.title: Need help with simple general programming if possible!
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Bowser jr: I never said anything about static methods. Only static variables, which in most cases should be constants (that is static final and immutable). Anyway, the description he was “given” really cannot be used. The last update I made of my last post contains some of my interpretations. It’s ambiguous. No construct in Java can be both an instance-variable and a static variable, for instance.

Read full topic
item.source: Need help with simple general programming if possible!

item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

object: And then you have a method that you can only use once, as you can’t get the result for a larger range. Which would would make the usage pretty limited.

Read full topic
item.source: Need help with simple general programming if possible!

item.title: Need help with simple general programming if possible!
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Bowser jr: That would probably be a static final (constant) variable.

I started trying to write the code in the description. This is my result:

public class FindPrimes {
    private [static] int limit;           //1.
    
    public FindPrimes() {               //2.
        [this|FindPrimes].limit = 0;
    }
    
    public FindPrimes(int limit) {    //3.
        if(limit < 0) {
            System.exit(0);
        } else {
            [this|FindPrimes].limit = limit;
        }
    }
    
    ...
}

Read full topic
item.source: Need help with simple general programming if possible!

item.title: Need help with simple general programming if possible!
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Also the class you’re ask to make is terrible. Do the assignment, but do not think that making your classes this way is a good idea. Having your methods be dependent on a static variable is a terrible idea if you ever where to use this in a multi-threaded program. Sure there is some instances where a static var is useful, but this is not one of them.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[code=java]//instance variable that is type static and int.
private static int upperBound;

//setter method for the user to change upperBounds value
public static void setUpperBound(int upperBound) {
this.upperBound = upperBound;
}[/code]

Step 1 completed!

//Constructor setting the upperBound limit to 0 public MyClass() { this.upperBound = 0; }

Step 2 done!

item.title: Need help with simple general programming if possible!
item.dc:creator: @leoshiro leoshiro
item.description:
@leoshiro wrote:

[quote=“Tree, post:4, topic:550519”]Okay, I’ll help you.
Stop. Being. Lazy.
Want to learn to program? Learn to problem solve.
I’m not sure if this is homework or self-study. Either way, homework generally isn’t assigned without accompanying resources. If it’s self-study from a book, the resources required to complete these activities are provided within the pages before these. If it’s from a website, Google each part.
We do not complete homework for you. We do not write code for you. We at least expect you to attempt the problem and then ask us specific questions, showing your attempt at the same time.

The different parts can almost be seen as instructions. Go through each one and eventually you will have completed the end goal. If you need extra help:
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/reallybigindex.html

Other than that, don’t post again until you have at least made an effort and tried to solve the problem yourself.

I know this comes off as harsh but I’m telling you this for your own good.
Good luck.[/quote] yea i know you have the right to say that , but i said help , and not do all the work instead of me , like just now u gave me a link and that helped me thanks alot anyways ^^ and thanks for ur advise i know i dont have the right to post that and let u do all the work

Read full topic

item.title: Need help with simple general programming if possible!
item.dc:creator: @leoshiro leoshiro
item.description:
@leoshiro wrote:

i need to code this can anyone help me or teach me if possible? please reply with any way i can contact you , thanks.
Write a Java Class called FindPrimes that computes and find the number of Prime numbers between 2 and an upper bound limit set by the user. The Class should comprise the following:

  1. An instance variable, limit, of type static and int to represent the upper bound limit.
  2. A non-parameterized constructor that sets limit to zero.
  3. A parameterized constructor that takes one integer parameter and sets limit to the value of the parameter. Before doing that it checks whether or not the value of the parameter is negative. If it is, the constructor ends the program.
  4. One mutator and one accessor method to set and get the value of the instance variable.
  5. A main() method where a Scanner object and a FindPrimes object are created. Then, the program finds the prime numbers between 2 and the value of the instance variable limit. To do this main() uses a method IsPrime() that checks whether or not a number is prime.
  6. The method IsPrime() takes an int argument (the number to be checked) and returns true if the number is prime and false if not.
  7. A prime number is a number that divides by 1 and by itself only. (Hint: for a given number r, divide r by 2, then by 3, …, until square root of r (inclusive), and check the remainder. if the remainder is zero 0 for any number between 2 and square root of r, then r is NOT prime).
  8. After computing the number of primes between 2 and limit, main() will display a ratio of the number of primes by the total of the number between 1 and limit. Example: between 1 and 30 the program should find 10 primes. The ratio of primes is
    (100) * 10/30 which 33.33 %

Read full topic
